name: A-Premium White
description: With an acidity level of 6%, this is a perfect transition from red wine or champagne vinegar into the realm of the balsamic. Residual sweetness takes the edge off the acid, and adds a wonderful complexity.  Pairs well with all of our oils.

name: Alfoos Mango
description: Balsamic with essence of the finest mangos, cultivated in India and known the world over for their sweetness. Pair with Milanese Gremolata olive oil to make salad greens come alive, or grill chicken with a Meyer Lemon/Alfoos Mango marinade.

name: Black Cherry
description: Balsamic blended with fresh black cherries for an outstanding, complex flavor, delicious as a glaze or on salad greens.  Pair with Fresh Garlic olive oil for flank steak.  Try a drizzle on ice cream.

name: Black Currant
description: Balsamic and natural black currants blended in perfect proportion, resulting in a new and unique flavor.  Just one taste will explain why this is a store favorite.  Pair with Meyer Lemon olive oil to make salad greens come alive.

name: Blackberry Ginger
description: Essence of blackberries with a hint of ginger.  Pair with Blood Orange or Persian Lime olive oils.  Reduce for dessert toppings, from cake to ice cream.

name: Blenheim Apricot
description: The deep, rich flavor of Blushing Blenheim apricots makes this white balsamic exceptional in dressings, marinades, and glazes.  Combine with Arbosana or Koroneiki olive oils to accentuate summery flavor.  For a real taste “pop”, mix with Tuscan Herb olive oils.

name: Cinnamon Pear
description: Balsamic blended with spicy cinnamon and golden pears is outstanding in a ham glaze, with seared duck breast, in dressings or as a drizzle over ice cream.  Pair it with Roasted Pumpkin Seed or Butternut Squash Seed oils for soups, roasted vegetables or salads.

name: Cranberry-Pear
description: Cranberries and pears blended with balsamic make a winning combination. The cranberries infuse a lovely color, as well as a not-too-sweet taste.  Pair with any citrus-fused olive oils — Blood Orange, Persian Lime or Meyer Lemon.

name: Dark Chocolate
description: Rich, thick and resounding with the complexity of three different chocolates, this balsamic works with sweet as well as savory recipes. In Mexican dishes, use it like mole. On the sweet side, top vanilla gelato, macerate fresh berries or drizzle on pound cake.

name: Espresso
description: Robust essence of espresso blends with balsamic to become a “secret ingredient” in recipes.  Makes a wonderful marinade for flank steak and perks up pan drippings for gravies.  It’s amazing on a salad of arugula and shaved parmesan.   Top vanilla or coffee ice cream.

name: Honey Ginger
description: Honey & ginger bring a gentle, spicy heat to the moderate acidity of white balsamic.  Superlative on salmon when paired with Persian Lime olive oil.  It positively shines with Japanese Roasted Sesame oil in an Asian stir-fry.

name: Lavender
description: Lavender from the fields of France is blended with 18-year balsamic for a taste sensation.  Think of lavender only as a room scent?  Think again!  Pair with Herbes de Provence olive oil for salads, marinades, or dips.   It makes a wonderful marinade for grilled chicken.

name: Madagascar Vanilla
description: The best vanilla beans and 18-year balsamic combine in a mouthwatering treat for salads, marinades and sauces.  Makes a fantastic base for grilled chicken.  Equally delicious when drizzled on ice cream, sliced strawberries or other fresh fruits.

name: Neapolitan Herb
description: Zesty, infused with herbs associated with southern Italian cuisine — garlic, rosemary, marjoram, thyme, sage.  Loves salads, grilled vegetables, and meat marinades.  Great in a Bloody (or Virgin) Mary!!

name: Oregano
description: Less sweet than the usual balsamics, this one is delicious in vegetable and seafood salads, on grilled vegetables, and in savory marinades.  Pair with Fresh Garlic or Tuscan Herb olive oils to create a one-of-a-kind vinaigrette.

name: Pomegranate
description: The pomegranate essence add extra natural antioxidants to this 12-year balsamic.  Delicious as a glaze or on salad greens.  Pair with Blood Orange olive oil, or Roasted Almond oil for great salads.

name: Raspberry
description: Ripe red raspberry essence adds a pleasing splash of freshness to salads.  The aroma is mouth-watering in itself.  It delights as a drizzle over fruit and ice cream.  Try pairing  with our Meyer Lemon or Persian Lime olive oils.

name: Red Apple
description: Apple essence gives this blend great complex flavor.  In addition to making a delicious salad with apple pieces, toasted walnuts and bleu or goat cheese crumbles, try it in pork or veal recipes.  Add to vegetables roasted with Sweet Almond or Butternut Squash Seed oil.

name: Sicilian Lemon
description: Combines the tartness of lemons with the sweetness of balsamics.  Pair with Wild Fernleaf Dill olive oil for a zesty salad vinaigrette or a fish marinade.  Especially delicious drizzled over steamed or sautéed greens like kale, spinach, chard, or collards.

name: Strawberry
description: Bold berry flavor, both sweet and tart, adds a pleasing splash of freshness to salads, fruit and ice cream, and the bouquet is mouthwatering.  It pairs perfectly with our Persian Lime olive oil.

name: Succulent Fig
description: A must for every kitchen pantry.  It is an excellent choice to drizzle over any salad.  Pair with Blood Orange or Basil olive oil for poultry dishes, dressing and marinades.

name: Tangerine
description: Citrus lovers will find this blend to their taste.  Delicious mixed with Blood Orange olive oil -- in a salad with halved tangerine segments -- or in a marinade with soy sauce for an orange chicken stir-fry.

name: Traditional 18-Year Old
description: Our best seller!  Aged up to 18 years, it compares with much older (and more expensive!) balsamics.  Delicious on and with everything, from appetizers to entrees to desserts.  Try adding a dash to sparkling water for a refreshing low-cal drink.

name: Denissimo
description: An exquisite and exceedingly rare aged reduced balsamic (1.36 density), boasting flavor notes of cherry wood, dried fruits, and figs, with hints of dark chocolate and malt.  Serve with fine cheeses, drizzle over fruit, use as a finishing glaze when roasting.

name: Tropical Coconut
description: White balsamic and coconut are blended for a refreshing flavor straight out of the Caribbean. Pair with Persian Lime olive oil — like a piña colada for seafood, shellfish or salad.

name: Vermont Maple
description: Maple syrup blended with aged balsamic is sheer genius.  Sweet and tart, it makes a tasty glaze for ham or pork.  Try in a fall-inspired salad, with pieces of pear or apple; or drizzle over crepes.  Pair with Roasted Pumpkin or Butternut Squash Seed oils.

name: White Peach
description: White balsamic vinegar and juicy peaches make a great sweet-tart combination. The sweet peach flavor makes salad greens taste amazing.  Pair with Blood Orange olive oil to grill salmon or shrimp.
